body: FOLLOWING the clearance of a backlog of applications, 69 areas of New York City are now listed on the Federal and State Historic Registers. Unlike landmark designation by the city, which imposes restraints on facade alterations, the state and national listings impose no restrictions on privately sponsored projects. Lengthy review is necessary,
title: 69 CITY DISTRICTS DUBBED HISTORIC

body: While some Brooklyn neighborhoods like Cobble Hill, Carroll Gardens, Boerum Hill and Park Slope stand as shining examples of the borough's recent rebirth, the immediate vicinity around the Brooklyn Academy of Music has continued to deteriorate. ''We are in a commercial rather than residential area where the buildings do not hold the same esthetic
title: POSTINGS;

body: Fan of Rangers Nick Fotiu and Barry Beck of the Rangers are scheduled to go this afternoon to visit David Rothenberg, the 7-year-old boy who was burned over 90 percent of his body by his father last March. David, who lives in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn, is a fan of the Yankees and the Giants, but says the Rangers are his favorite team,
title: SCOUTING

body: FOR years Cobble Hill was called a poor man's Brooklyn Heights. But no longer. ''Not when you've got houses selling for $425,000,'' said Penelope Karagias, a local real-estate broker. ''That's not remotely the case anymore.'' Cobble Hill, a 22-block area south of Brooklyn Heights bordered by Atlantic Avenue and Hicks, DeGraw and Court Streets, has
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: COBBLE HILL

body: It was the first day of public school yesterday, a day of rituals and promise for nearly a million children all over the city. At Public School 58, an elementary school in the heart of Brooklyn, it began as it had for the last 26 years, as an event embraced by the neighborhood. By 8:30 A.M., the parents had gathered outside the three-story yellow
title: AS SCHOOL BELLS RING, A DAY OF BEGINNINGS AND MEMORIES OF THINGS PAST

body: Today is Labor Day, a chance for reflection as much as celebration. David W. Dunlap of The New York Times asked five union officials in their 30's what brought them to the labor movement and what they hoped to bring to it, what - if anything - made modern union work different from that of the past. One of the officials lived a childhood steeped in
title: LABOR OFFICIALS LOOK AHEAD AND BACK

body: Howard Golden, the Borough President of Brooklyn, stood yesterday in an elegantly restored room of Borough Hall and for a moment reflected on what history had done. ''This used to be the Mayor of Brooklyn's grand ballroom,'' Mr. Golden said, looking about at the large red-marble columns and recalling the days when Brooklyn was a city all its own.
title: EX-DODGERS JOIN IN GOING HOME AGAIN

body: A 38-year-old police officer was has been convicted of seconddegree assault for striking a handcuffed prisoner on the head with his nightstick in a Brooklyn station house. A jury in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn returned the verdict Tuesday against Vincent Piscitelli, a member of the force for 13 years until his suspension shortly after the
title: OFFICER IS FOUND GUILTY OF HITTING CUFFED PRISONER

body: IT WAS, said Salvadore Scotto, a surprise. In the early 1960's, the b rownstoners began to trickle in, first into Cobble Hill, across A tlantic Avenue from Brooklyn Heights, and then farther south into h is neighborhood, an Italian enclave that had its own identity but n ot a name, a place that some called South Brooklyn and others simply' 'the
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: CARROLL GARDENS

body: For writers, Brooklyn has never been primarily the borough of the Bridge. Borough of churches, borough of nostalgia, borough of hope (for Dodgers fans), it is above all a piece of geography or, if you prefer, a considerable piece of real estate. Literary visitors have found it an urban alternative to Manhattan's desperate pursuit of the present.
title: BROOKLYN, BOROUGH OF WRITERS

body: At 7 A.M. yesterday, 24 rear-loading garbage trucks pulled out of the Sanitation Department's Brooklyn West 6 garage at 127 Second Avenue. For eight hours, they moved through the Carroll Gardens, Cobble Hill, Gowanus, Park Slope and Red Hook sections, collecting more than 12 tons of garbage each. What was there about all that to prompt Commissioner
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; Money-Saving Move In Trash Collection
